I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  A preparatory meeting to establish a Regional Business Roundtable1 (RBR) was held on 
3–4 November 2005, in Bishkek, the Kyrgyz Republic prior to the Fourth Ministerial Conference 
on  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC).  The  CAREC  program  covers 
Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, the People’s Republic of 
China (focusing on the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region), Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. During 
the meeting, the RBR was endorsed as a mechanism to enhance private sector participation 
among the ongoing regional cooperation programs—especially CAREC. The Bishkek Action 
Plan2 summarized discussions and agreements of the RBR meeting. The action plan was 
submitted  to  and  discussed  at  the  CAREC  senior  officials’  meeting  and  endorsed  by  the 
ministerial conference. 
 
2.  It  was  agreed  at  the  preparatory  meeting  that  the  RBR  would  focus  initially  on 
channeling the interests of member countries' private sectors to various regional cooperation 
programs, including CAREC and the Subregional Economic Cooperation in South and Central 
Asia (formerly known as the Central and South Asia Trade and Transport Forum). Participants 
proposed that, in addition to the core activities of CAREC (trade facilitation, trade policy, energy, 
and transport), the RBR agenda focus on the financial sector and tourism.  
 
3.  Subsequent  to  the  November  2005  RBR,  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC) 
suggested that CAREC hold a business development forum (BDF) for Central Asia in 2006 or 
early 2007 in order to deepen awareness of the role that the private sector should play in 
regional cooperation. 
 
4.  Discussion and finalization of the activities described above will culminate in the first 
official meeting of the CAREC BDF in conjunction with the Fifth CAREC ministerial conference 
on Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation, planned for October 2006.3 The CAREC BDF 
should be held in advance of these official meetings so that the outcome, recommendations, 
and next steps can be discussed and endorsed accordingly. In addition to the CAREC program 
countries, Iran, Pakistan, Russia, and Turkmenistan will also be invited to attend the BDF. The 
technical assistance (TA) design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  To date, input from key stakeholders in the private sector has been lacking under the 
CAREC program. Despite repeated vows from ministers and senior officials to encourage more 
private sector participation in regional cooperation projects and activities, this proposed regional 
technical assistance (RETA) would be only the second private sector development initiative 
since CAREC was launched in 1997 (the other was the CAREC's 2005 regional business 
roundtable). 
 
                                                 
1  The Regional Business Roundtable was a joint initiative between Central Asia Regional Cooperation (CAREC) and 
the Subregional Economic Cooperation in South and Central Asia, which was managed by ADB's South Asia 
Department before the realignment of the ADB's regional departments effective 1 May 2006. 
2  The Bishkek Action Plan contains the participants’ ideas and agreements in terms of the RBR’s vision and 
objectives, benefits, substantive activities, key success factors, possible structures and mechanisms, and next 
steps. 
3  The CAREC BDF initiative will be implemented by the ADB with close support from the European Bank for 
Reconstruction and Development with its extensive private sector experience.

2     
6.  With the exception of one TA to date, minimal attention was devoted to private sector 
development  until  the  First  Ministerial  Conference  on  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic 
Cooperation in March 2002, which noted that trade and transport within Central Asia and with 
other countries is vital for private sector development. Private sector development gained further 
attention at the Third Ministerial Conference on Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation in 
2004, when ministers declared in a joint ministerial statement that they “... also endorsed the 
recommendation that private sector participation in the CAREC program should be encouraged 
and facilitated.”  
 
7.  Although the CAREC program lacks direct experience in private sector development in 
the region, various studies and forums in Central Asia offer important insights that have been 
incorporated into the design of this RETA. Among these are: 
 
(i)  One needs the right approach to the private sector. If the private sector is to be a 
major  source  of  funds  in  infrastructure  development,  it  must  be  invited  to 
participate from the moment projects are conceived.4  
(ii)  The private sector looks for sectors with high returns and high growth.5 
(iii)  A more vibrant Central Asia business sector depends greatly upon the public 
sector providing a conducive environment for business. This includes easing 
barriers to the flow of people and goods, establishing effective and responsive 
public agencies, providing a solid legal and regulatory framework to underpin the 
business sector, and developing infrastructure.6   
 
8.  The  major  conclusions  of  the  RBR  preparatory  meeting  were  that  private  sector 
representation in regional cooperation meetings needed to be enhanced, and that the interests 
of the region’s domestic and foreign businesses must be reflected in the various regional 
cooperation programs. The proposed BDF will focus on meeting this objective and promoting 
public–private partnerships in key projects. 
 
9.  The main objectives of the CAREC BDF meeting are as follows: 
 
(i)  To bring together public and private sector investors to identify major investment 
opportunities and inform the ministerial conference about existing barriers that 
preclude such investments; 
(ii)  To leverage the vast amount of information available in the public and donor 
sectors to support private sector investments; 
(iii)  To  identify  the  major  constraints  to  investment  in  the  target  sectors  and  to 
develop mechanisms to address these constraints; 
(iv)  To support the development of the hard and soft infrastructure required to foster 
greater trade and investment activities both within CAREC and with neighboring 
countries; 
(v)  To foster the linkages that must exist between all private sector participants in 
the region in order to ensure the expansion of markets, the development of intra-
regional  supply  chains,  and  the  integrated  financial  systems  that  regional 
cooperation ultimately fosters and nurtures;

5  See footnote 4.  
6  ADB. 2004. Issues in and Options for Private Sector Development in the Central Asian Region. Manila.

3
(vi)  To enhance business sector involvement in the CAREC initiatives by providing 
direct  and  regular  channels  for  the  private  sector  to  communicate  with  the 
governments participating in the CAREC program; and 
(vii)  To lay the groundwork for sustainable structures and institutional mechanisms to 
perpetuate the development of public–private partnerships and private sector 
involvement in regional cooperation projects. 
 
10.  The  proposed  CAREC  BDF  meeting  in  October  will  examine  the  region’s  priority 
investment opportunities and how to overcome the existing obstacles to investment in five 
sectors identified in the Bishkek Action Plan, namely: (i) energy (oil and gas), (ii) mining, (iii) 
banking and finance; (iv) agribusiness, and (v) tourism.  
 
11.  For each of the five sectors, and in close conjunction with all key players—the business 
communities both within and outside the region, multilateral institutions involved in the CAREC 
program (i.e., the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, International Monetary 
Fund, Islamic Development Bank, United Nations Development Programme, and World Bank),7 
investment  banks,  investment  promotion  agencies,  and  others—it  is  proposed  to  produce 
sector-specific  investment  materials.  These  materials  will  be  carefully  produced  by  the 
secretariat  in  cooperation  with  selected  multilateral  institutions  to  ensure  that  they  are  of 
maximum value to the business community.  
 
12.  In addition to the five sectors, and in line with the directions outlined in the Bishkek 
Action Plan, the CAREC BDF will consider a panel discussion on the critical area of enhancing 
trade  and  investment  in  the  region.  Accordingly,  the  CAREC  BDF  can  make  concrete 
recommendations to CAREC on required improvements in trade and investment-related areas.  
 
13.  It is proposed that another panel discussion be held on the key policy reforms required 
to  strengthen  the  infrastructure  base  in  the  CAREC  region,  issues  relating  to  financing 
infrastructure, and the potential for public–private partnerships in infrastructure.  
 
14.  At the at the start of the respective sectoral discussion groups at the CAREC BDF, 
selected  investment  banks—and  possibly  multinational  and  large  domestic  corporations 
operating in the CAREC region—will provide introductory presentations on the structure and key 
issues of the energy, mining, agriculture, tourism, and finance sectors, and on potential cross-
border investment opportunities. In addition, the individual discussion groups will help identify 
various legal and regulatory barriers to cross-border or regional investment in these sectors. 
The key findings put forward by the investors will be validated by key private sector players in 
these industries. The CAREC BDF will then formulate specific proposals to reduce impediments 
to regional private sector development to the senior officials’ meeting and ministerial conference 
for consideration and action. 
 
15.  Recognizing the key role to be played by the CAREC BDF in fostering an enabling 
environment for the private sector and strengthening the role of the business community in 
regional cooperation programs, the following significant contributions of the CAREC BDF to the 
business community have been identified: 
 
(i)  Serving as a focal point or intermediary between the public and private sectors in 
the CAREC program; 
                                                 
7  The multilateral institutions are not contributing financially to this BDF, but they are also involved in planning the 
event and will likely contribute experts as panelists and moderators.

4     
(ii)  Fostering greater coordination and networking amongst chambers of commerce 
and the general business sectors in the Central Asian countries; 
(iii)  Creating greater awareness of the common challenges and obstacles of doing 
business in Central Asia and undertaking concerted action, particularly in cross-
border facilitation issues, both within Central Asia and with neighbors; 
(iv)  Achieving  “economies  of  scale”  in  investment  opportunities,  training,  and 
leverage of donor inputs and business-related activities; 
(v)  Establishing  critical  links  with  major  international  organizations  supporting 
CAREC; and 
(vi)  Creating another point of access for CAREC BDF members to public agencies at 
the national, regional, and international levels. 
 
16.  The CAREC BDF meeting is a complex exercise requiring a wide range of activities for 
success. The following success factors for the CAREC BDF have been identified: 
 
(i)  A considerable amount of groundwork must be completed in order to ensure a 
productive and fruitful CAREC BDF meeting; in particular, suitable participants 
must be identified; 
(ii)  The ADB CAREC Unit and CAREC regional cooperation officers at the various 
ADB resident missions must take the lead in organizing and coordinating many 
different events. Current staff resources need to be supported by temporary staff 
members  to  assist  with  contacting  potential  speakers  and  participants  and 
related activities. 
(iii)  The  planning  and  implementation  of  the  CAREC  BDF  must  be  done  in 
collaboration with other multilateral institution partners; 
(iv)  In order for the CAREC BDF initiatives to succeed, a mechanism within CAREC 
must be developed to involve the private sector actively at various levels in the 
regional cooperation process on a consistent basis; 
(v)  Public sector activities should, where possible, be refocused to explicitly take into 
account constructive private sector perspectives;  
(vi)  Considerable effort goes into preparing BDF industry sector briefs and other 
supporting materials; and 
(vii)  Required resources must be mobilized to cover all aspects of the meeting (as 
was the case with the RBR meeting in November 2005). 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
17.  The impact of the RETA will be improved investment, trade, and transport conditions in 
the CAREC region resulting from the establishment of an effective forum for private sector 
feedback and input into CAREC. The outcome of the RETA will be that the business community 
will be able to participate more fully in regional investment projects in the five priority sectors in 
the CAREC economies. The RETA will support the actions called for in the Bishkek Action Plan 
in November 2005 at the preparatory meeting of the RBR. The RETA will also support the 
preparation required to ensure a successful first meeting of the CAREC BDF in October 2006. 
This meeting will aim to achieve the following objectives: (i) establishment of an effective public–
private sector partnership mechanism for regional cooperation in Central Asia; (ii) improvement 
of  the  business  environment  (government  policies,  regulations,  and  procedures);  and  (iii) 
capacity building of private sector participants to undertake regional business.

5
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
18.  Extensive consultations with the CAREC member countries and participating multilateral 
institutions will be required to plan and successfully hold the CAREC BDF. Consultations with all 
of the key stakeholders, including those from the private sector, have been ongoing since March 
2006 when the initial concept paper on the CAREC BDF was drafted. The concept paper 
received  endorsement  at  the  CAREC  senior  officials’  meeting  in  April  2006,  which  led  to 
subsequent discussions and consensus building among stakeholders about the scope, agenda, 
and overall planning for the BDF. The basic structure of the CAREC BDF meeting under 
preparation is presented in Appendix 3; the basic tasks for the RETA consultants are presented 
in Appendix 4. 
 
19.  The key activities of the RETA will be: (i) preparation of background and issues papers 
for  the  five  key  sectors  to  be  discussed  at  the  October  2006  CAREC  BDF  meeting;  (ii) 
establishment  of  linkages  with  other  regional  business  groups  and  national  business 
associations, (iii) implementation of all steps required to prepare for the October 2006 CAREC 
BDF meeting; (iv) holding the October 2006 CAREC BDF meeting, and (v) preparation of 
documentation to support the development of the CAREC BDF after the meeting and to report 
to the CAREC ministerial conference.8  
 
C.  Cost and Financing Plan 
20.  The total cost of the RETA is estimated at $200,000 equivalent. The RETA will be 
financed on a grant basis by the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional 
Cooperation Fund and administered by ADB.  Detailed cost estimates and a financing plan are 
given in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  ADB will be the Executing Agency of the RETA. The PRC Ministry of Finance and 
Ministry of Commerce will be the Implementing Agencies. The RETA will be implemented over 4 
months (August 2006–November 2006). The final RETA report will be finished by the end of 
November 2006. The RETA will be administered by the CAREC Unit, with ADB's Private Sector 
Operations Department providing overall guidance. 
 
22.  The RETA will require the services of a national consultant with an expertise in events 
management from August–October 2006.9 The consultant will be responsible for preparing for 
and managing the October 2006 CAREC BDF. The consultant will assist with the development, 
implementation, promotion, and operation of the BDF, including coordinating closely with the 
Implementing Agencies of the RETA, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development,

CAREC private sector. The preparatory meeting discussed options for the RBR being held biannually or annually, 
and the first “full” meeting of the RBR was going to decide this. However, subsequent discussions with multilateral 
institutions and the PRC Government led to the BDF concept, and hence the RBR has been folded into the BDF. 
The BDF will hopefully become a regular mechanism for private sector inputs to and participation in the CAREC 
program, provided that the member governments and other multilateral institutions concur and that sufficient 
interest and ownership is demonstrated by the private sector. 
9  Under the CAREC umbrella RETA, a private sector specialist/international consultant was engaged to provide 
overall guidance in preparing for the BDF. The consultant is responsible for consultations with key stakeholders; 
preparing sector background briefs, other documentation relevant to the BDF discussions, and a post-BDF 
strategic action plan; and assisting with organizing and implementing logistics for the meeting participants.

and the All China Federation of Industry and Commerce. The consultant will be recruited by 
ADB on an individual basis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation 
Fund  for  Support  Preparations  for  the  CAREC  Business  Development  Forum,  and  hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

additional day for country presentations or discussions on specific projects as required, will 
consist mainly of discussion groups focusing on the identification of practical opportunities and 
partnerships in each of the five sectors. In addition, the meeting will seek opportunities for 
enhancing private sector involvement in the activities of the Central Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation (CAREC) discussion groups.1

groups for their action.) 
 
16:45-17:00  Break for Preparation of Discussion Group Presentations 
 
17:00-18:00  Presentations of Key Findings from the Discussion Groups back to Plenary 
 
 
Day 2: October 17, 2006 
 
On Day 2, meeting facilities will be made available for networking and discussions on specific 
projects to support any of the participants who would like to continue specific discussions on 
investment projects.  
 
09:00-11:00  Networking  and  Discussions  on  Specific  Projects/Initiatives  (It  is 
recommended that rooms be allocated for country delegations to facilitate these 
networking meetings as well as to provide an opportunity for country delegations 
to disseminate information on doing business in their countries.) 
 
11:00-12:00  CAREC Business Development Forum Conclusions (These should consider, 
among  other  things,  the  need  for  structures and  mechanisms  to ensure  the 
sustainability of the CAREC Business Development Forum and the ongoing role 
of the secretariat.) 
 
12:00-14:00  Lunch

Appendix 4  13 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE 
 EVENT MANAGEMENT SPECIALIST 
 
1.  An event management specialist will be engaged for the period 15 August to 31 October 
2006, with the primary responsibility of preparing for and managing the Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Business Development Forum (BDF) to be held in October 
2006. This assignment will involve the following key tasks, which are broken down into two main 
categories: 
 
A.  Content 
 
2.  The  event  management  specialist  will  undertake  the  following  to  ensure  that  all 
substantive aspects of the BDF are carried out: 
  
(i)  Assist with the development, implementation, promotion, and operation of the 
BDF, including liaison and coordination with the Ministry of Commerce of the 
People’s Republic of China, European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, 
and All China Federation of Industry and Commerce, as well as with speakers, 
internal resource and service providers, and possible third-party providers. 
 
(ii)  Conduct  all  correspondence,  invitations,  and  registration  arrangements  with 
prospective and actual participants, and assist with communication, briefings, 
and arrangements for all resource persons, including speakers and support staff 
(including the creation and maintenance of all conference-related databases). 
 
(iii)  Assist with evaluating and documenting the BDF, including preparing breakout 
session  summaries  and  highlights  for  the  guidance  of  the  BDF  chair,  the 
chairman’s  report  to  be  submitted  to  the  CAREC  ministerial  conference  for 
endorsement, and a post-conference report that summarizes the feedback of 
participants,  and  the  subsequent  preparation  and  distribution  of  conference 
materials including pre- and post-conference website promotion, and possible 
follow-up  activities  including  the  design,  production,  and  distribution  of 
conference materials electronically and otherwise. 
 
(iv)  Work with ADB on media relations, including pre- and post-conference publicity, 
possible interviews, preparing press kits, media coaching prior to press briefings 
during the BDF, and media monitoring. 
   
B.  Logistics  
 
3.  In terms of all logistical aspects of the BDF, the events management specialist will 
undertake to coordinate with ADB, the Ministry of Commerce of the People’s Republic of China, 
and  China  International  Center  for  International  and  Technology  Exchanges  on  local 
arrangements for the venue of the BDF and other related activities (technical, banqueting 
services, transportation, translation and interpretation services, printing services, and security, 
as required) including the provision of third-party service providers to supplement the internal 
services and resources of ADB.
